body.p: To his Excellency Governor Bramblette of Ky.

The undersigned petitioners respectfully state that at the August Term 1863 of the Campbell Circuit Court Sebastian Gramer was fined for keeping a Tipling house the Sum of sixty dollars & costs This is an exceedingly hard case, agst. a very poor man, and is in our judgement such as calls for Executive clemency.

sd Gramer is a German unacquainted with the laws of Kentucky & has always looked upon Native wine ^(as he says)^ to be as natural and innocent a drink as water. He was keeping a small grocery in Jamestown and obtained a license to sell beer from the Trustees. This, Gramer innocently supposed justified at least ^the sale of^ Native wine. It was proven by one witness on the trial (Charles Slain) that Gramer had let him have native wine as often as two or three times & this was all the evidence. We as jurors who tried the case and as citizens of the immediate vicinity respectfully ask the Governor to remit this fine & we are satisfied that public justice will not suffer & that Mr Gramer will never again offend agst the law which he has innocently done as we believe in this case.
Sept. 18. 1863

Campbell Circuit Court
August 5th 1863
Commonwealth
vs, On Indictment
S. Gramer

The parties appeared and the defendant plead not guilty thereupon came a Jury, viz: J. O. Prather, J. Constans, P. H. Kemper, Lewis Donahower, Wm M. Neyman, S. Allen, John Butcher, John Nelson, Thos. Marston, Chas. Murnan, Geo. Summers & B. Caruthers: who were sworn to try the issue after hearing the evidence returned the following verdict, viz: "We the jury find the defend't guilty of keeping a tippling house as charged in the indictment, P.A.C. Kemper, foreman." It is therefore adjudged that the commonwealth recover of the defendant a fine of Sixty Dollars, and the costs of this proceeding; and that the defendant stand convicted until the fine is paid such commutal not to exceed 30 days.

A Copy Attest, Gus. Arttman, C. C. C.
by H. Sine, D.C
